column9: the reversal of the normal word order in a sentence, especially the placing of a verb before its subject.
column10: This one is all about grammar - sentence structure... and all the times when the normal structure gets inverted.
column11: 'Rarely do I eat pizza' is an example of inversion.
column12: Inversions are often used for emphasis or in formal language.

column9: the grammatical arrangement of words in sentences.
column10: This one is all about grammar - sentence structure, to be specific.
column11: The normal sentence structure in English is Subject-Verb-Object (SVO).
column12: Understanding sentence structure is key to improving your grammar.

column9: the categories to which words are assigned based on their syntactic functions (e.g., noun, verb, adjective).
column10: What are the parts of speech?
column11: Nouns, verbs, and adjectives are the basic parts of speech.
column12: Learning the parts of speech is a fundamental part of grammar.

column9: phrases that function as adverbs, modifying a verb, adjective, or clause.
column10: ...we'll be looking at various adverbial expressions which are used at the beginning of a sentence...
column11: 'On the other hand' is a common adverbial expression.
column12: Adverbial expressions can add detail about time, place, or manner.

column9: sentences expressing factual implications or hypothetical situations and their consequences.
column10: ...inversions with negative and limiting adverbials, inversions in conditionals...
column11: The first, second, and third conditionals are used to talk about different types of hypothetical situations. 15882,
column12: Inversions can be used in formal conditional sentences instead of 'if'.

column9: to gain a better understanding or control of something.
column10: ...this episode should help you get a better grip on the grammar of sentences in English...
column11: I need to get a better grip on my finances.
column12: After studying, she felt she had a better grip on the subject.

column9: unable to answer a question or solve a problem.
column10: I was actually stumped by the question 'What is a noun, verb, adjective?'.
column11: The last question on the quiz completely stumped me.
column12: Even the experts were stumped by the mysterious phenomenon.

column9: ways in which something is usually done.
column10: This is going to be a proper look at the conventions of sentence structure...
column11: You need to follow the conventions of formal letter writing.
column12: Social conventions vary from culture to culture.

column9: the normal, standard word order for sentences in English.
column10: The normal structure in English is S V O (Subject Verb Object).
column11: 'I eat pizza' is an example of an SVO sentence.
column12: In questions, the SVO structure is often inverted.

column9: the inverted word order used in questions and after certain adverbials.
column10: ...the usual structure is SVO which gets inverted in questions to ASV...
column11: 'Do you like pizza?' follows the ASV structure.
column12: The inversion follows this pattern: Auxiliary verb + subject + verb (A S V).

column9: a verb used to form the tenses, moods, and voices of other verbs (e.g., be, do, have).
column10: The inversion follows this pattern: Auxiliary verb + subject + verb.
column11: All verbs have an auxiliary, except BE.
column12: In the sentence 'I have finished', 'have' is the auxiliary verb.

column9: questions that ask about the subject of a sentence and do not use inversion.
column10: Let's say the missing information is the subject of the sentence... There's no inversion in subject questions.
column11: 'Who ate all the pizzas?' is a subject question.
column12: In subject questions, the question word replaces the subject.

column9: questions that ask about the object of a sentence and require an auxiliary verb and inversion.
column10: These are the more normal questions that you are used to. They involve an inversion...
column11: 'What do you eat?' is an object question.
column12: Object questions can be either yes/no questions or WH- questions.

column9: adverbs or adverbial phrases that have a negative meaning (e.g., 'never', 'rarely', 'not only').
column10: Inversion after Negative or Limiting Adverbials.
column11: When you start a sentence with a negative adverbial, you must use inversion.
column12: 'Never before' and 'on no account' are examples of negative adverbials.

column9: adverbs or adverbial phrases that restrict the meaning of a verb or clause (e.g., 'only then', 'little').
column10: Inversion after Negative or Limiting Adverbials.
column11: Limiting adverbials at the start of a sentence also require inversion.
column12: 'Only in this way' is a limiting adverbial.

column9: feeling or showing that you think you are more important than other people.
column10: The second one sounds quite pompous, self-important, arrogant, formal, old fashioned.
column11: He's a pompous old man who's always talking about his achievements.
column12: Her speech was pompous and full of long, unnecessary words.

column9: having an exaggerated sense of one's own value or importance.
column10: The second one sounds quite pompous, self-important, arrogant...
column11: I can't stand his self-important attitude.
column12: She's so self-important, she thinks the world revolves around her.

column9: unpleasantly proud and behaving as if you are more important than, or know more than, other people.
column10: The second one sounds quite pompous, self-important, arrogant...
column11: He's so arrogant he thinks he's always right.
column12: I found his manner to be arrogant and dismissive.

column9: concerning the writing, study, or content of literature.
column10: ...these sentences with negative adverbials and inversions tend to be a bit more formal sounding, maybe quite literary...
column11: 'The Lord of the Rings' is a classic of literary fiction.
column12: She is a respected literary critic.

column9: of high quality or for people of high social class.
column10: ...moving towards something like up-market English.
column11: They live in an up-market part of the city.
column12: The hotel has an up-market restaurant.

column9: having or showing qualities that are considered professional and efficient.
column10: This kind of English is impressive, businesslike and proper.
column11: She has a very businesslike manner.
column12: The meeting was conducted in a businesslike way.

column9: almost no; almost not; almost none.
column10: I hardly slept last night.
column11: I could hardly hear what she was saying.
column12: There's hardly any food left.

column9: almost never.
column10: We hardly ever see each other these days.
column11: I hardly ever go to the cinema anymore.
column12: It hardly ever rains in this part of the country.

column9: used to say that something happened immediately after something else. Requires inversion.
column10: Hardly had we finished our breakfast when the prime minister came on the TV.
column11: Hardly had I got in the shower when the phone rang.
column12: This structure is very formal and literary.

column9: used to say that something happened immediately after something else. Requires inversion.
column10: No sooner had the Prime Minister made the statement than MPs were calling for his resignation.
column11: No sooner had she arrived than she started to complain.
column12: This structure emphasizes the immediacy of the second action.

column9: never in the past. Requires inversion at the start of a sentence.
column10: Never before had I heard such terrible lies from a Prime Minister.
column11: Never before has our country faced such a crisis.
column12: It was a sight I had never before witnessed.

column9: rarely; not often.
column10: Seldom do we witness such amazing displays of political maneuvering.
column11: He seldom goes out.
column12: It's seldom that we see such a beautiful sunset.

column9: not often.
column10: Rarely will you see such widespread derision of a public figure.
column11: I rarely drink coffee.
column12: She is rarely seen in public.

column9: used to give two pieces of information, with the second one adding to and often emphasizing the first. The 'not only' part requires inversion if at the start.
column10: Not only did he lie to the people but he also lied to the Queen.
column11: The car is not only economical but also feels good to drive.
column12: Not only is he a great actor, but he is also a talented musician.

column9: used to say that something happened immediately after something else. Requires inversion.
column10: Scarcely had his political career taken off when it crashed in full view of the public.
column11: Scarcely had she finished speaking when the phone rang.
column12: This structure is very formal and similar to 'hardly... when...'.

column9: in or to no place.
column10: Nowhere have I ever seen so many members of the press gathered in one place.
column11: I have nowhere to go.
column12: The keys were nowhere to be found.

column9: used to say that someone did not know something that was true. Requires inversion.
column10: Little did he know what was waiting for him!
column11: Little did I know that my life was about to change forever.
column12: This is a common literary device.

column9: not at all.
column10: In no way do I agree with what he said he had to do.
column11: In no way should this be considered a failure.
column12: This is in no way your fault.

column9: under no circumstances.
column10: On no account should you do anything like that at home.
column11: On no account should this door be left unlocked.
column12: This phrase is very formal and emphatic.

column9: used to say that something should never be done.
column10: Under no circumstances should you talk about this matter with anyone.
column11: Under no circumstances are you to leave this room.
column12: This is a very strong and formal prohibition.

column9: used to emphasize that something did not happen before a particular time. Inversion occurs in the main clause.
column10: Not until I saw him with my own eyes did I really believe he was telling the truth.
column11: Not until the next morning did she realize her mistake.
column12: This structure adds emphasis to the timing of the event.

column9: used to emphasize that something happened only after another event. Inversion occurs in the main clause.
column10: Only after I'd read his memoir did I understand why he did what he did.
column11: Only after he apologized did she agree to speak to him.
column12: This structure highlights the condition that had to be met first.

column9: used to emphasize that something happened only at a particular moment. Inversion occurs in the main clause.
column10: Only when everyone had read his story did the nation choose to forgive him.
column11: Only when the sun went down did it start to get cool.
column12: It's a formal way to structure a sentence for emphasis.

column9: used to emphasize that something was only possible by a particular method. Inversion occurs in the main clause.
column10: Only by working extremely hard could he rescue his political career.
column11: Only by practicing every day can you become a master.
column12: This is a common structure in formal and literary English.

column9: phrases that describe location, often causing inversion when placed at the start of a sentence for literary effect.
column10: Inversions after adverbials of place at the start of a sentence.
column11: 'Up the hill' and 'Round the corner' are adverbials of place.
column12: In literary style, you can say 'Down the road was my future' instead of 'My future was down the road'.

column9: a formal, inverted way of saying 'If you choose...'. Used in 1st conditionals.
column10: Should you choose to continue, you will have to pay.
column11: Should you require further assistance, please do not hesitate to contact us.
column12: This structure is common in formal letters and notices.

column9: a formal, inverted way of saying 'If I were...'. Used in 2nd conditionals for unreal present situations.
column10: Were I a millionaire, I would buy a house.
column11: Were I in your position, I would do the same thing.
column12: This form sounds quite old-fashioned or literary.

column9: a formal, inverted way of saying 'If you were to...'. Used in 2nd conditionals for unlikely future events.
column10: Were you to become Prime Minister, we'd all be in a lot of trouble!
column11: Were you to win the lottery, what would you do?
column12: This structure replaces 'if' with 'were' and uses a 'to-infinitive' for the main verb.

column9: a formal, inverted way of saying 'If he had...'. Used in 3rd conditionals for unreal past situations.
column10: Had he admitted his mistake earlier, he could have avoided a lot of trouble.
column11: Had I known you were coming, I would have baked a cake.
column12: This is the most common type of conditional inversion.

column2: So long was the episode that...
column9: an inverted structure used for emphasis, meaning 'The episode was so long that...'.
column10: So long was the episode that half the audience fell asleep while listening.
column11: So cold was the weather that the river froze over.
column12: This structure places 'So + adjective' at the beginning, followed by an inversion.

column9: questions that are embedded within another statement or question, which do not use inversion.
column10: Indirect questions (a kind of reverse inversion).
column11: 'Could you tell me what time it is?' is an indirect question.
column12: Indirect questions are more polite than direct questions.

column9: a grammatical construction occurring when two forms of negation are used in the same sentence, which is usually considered an error.
column10: Avoid double negatives.
column11: 'I don't know nothing' is a common double negative.
column12: Errors are often made by learners of English with inversions... when they make double negatives.

column9: an inverted phrase used to express strong disbelief or disagreement.
column10: Fuck off did you meet Paul McCartney.
column11: 'I won the lottery.' 'Fuck off did you!'
column12: This is a very rude and informal way to respond to someone.

column9: an inverted phrase used to express strong disbelief, meaning 'Nonsense'.
column10: Bollocks have you got a dinosaur at home.
column11: 'I'm the king of England.' 'Bollocks are you!'
column12: This is a very informal British English expression of disbelief.

column9: an inverted phrase used to express strong disbelief, meaning 'Nonsense'.
column10: Bullshit are you doing a TED Talk.
column11: 'I can fly.' 'Bullshit can you!'
column12: This is a common, though vulgar, way to tell someone you don't believe them.

column9: skilful or clever movement or management of affairs.
column10: Seldom do we witness such amazing displays of political maneuvering.
column11: The chess match was a brilliant display of tactical maneuvering.
column12: He was known for his clever political maneuvering.

column9: found or distributed over a large area or number of people.
column10: Rarely will you see such widespread derision of a public figure.
column11: There is widespread support for the new policy.
column12: The storm caused widespread damage.

column9: contemptuous ridicule or mockery.
column10: ...such widespread derision of a public figure.
column11: His comments were met with derision from the audience.
column12: She was an object of derision in her school.

column9: a historical account or biography written from personal knowledge.
column10: Only later did he really comment on the situation in his memoirs.
column11: She has written a memoir of her time as a war correspondent.
column12: His memoir became a bestseller.

column9: tending to cause disagreement or hostility between people.
column10: Not since Thatcher has the country seen such a divisive leader.
column11: The war was a very divisive issue.
column12: He is a divisive figure in the party.

column9: to save (someone) from a dangerous or difficult situation.
column10: Only by working extremely hard could he rescue his political career.
column11: The lifeboat rescued the sailors from the sinking ship.
column12: She rescued a cat from the animal shelter.

column9: (in folklore or fiction) a corpse that has been revived, such as a vampire or zombie.
column10: Up the hill marched the armies of the undead.
column11: The film is about a zombie apocalypse and the rise of the undead.
column12: He's a big fan of stories about vampires and the undead.

column9: a length of film containing microphotographs of the pages of a newspaper, catalogue, or other document.
column10: Should you not give me the location of the microfilm Mr Bond, you shall die...
column11: Old newspapers are often stored on microfilm in libraries.
column12: The spy stole the secret documents on microfilm.

column9: to deliberately ignore wrongdoing by others.
column10: Had it been another day, I might have looked the other way.
column11: The guards were bribed to look the other way.
column12: She saw him cheating, but she just looked the other way.

column9: to start doing something with energy and enthusiasm.
column10: So let's get stuck into inversions again.
column11: I need to get stuck into my revision for the exam.
column12: Come on, let's get stuck into the cleaning!

column9: competent or skilled in doing or using something.
column10: ...to become an advanced or proficient user of English.
column11: She is a proficient and experienced pianist.
column12: He became proficient in several languages.

column9: attracted and held the interest and attention of; charmed.
column10: So fascinating was the subject that the entire room was captivated...
column11: The children were captivated by the story.
column12: She was captivated by his charm.

column9: without hesitation or reluctance; willingly.
column10: So readily did they eat that it was obvious that they were starving.
column11: She readily agreed to help.
column12: Information is readily available on the internet.

column9: very hungry.
column10: ...it was obvious that they were starving.
column11: I'm starving, I haven't eaten all day.
column12: What's for dinner? I'm starving.

column9: to get through something quickly and forcefully.
column10: See if you can blast through this and get them all 100% correct!
column11: We need to blast through this work before the deadline.
column12: The team blasted through the opposition to win the tournament.

column9: in a direct and unflinchingly straightforward way.
column10: ...brutally disagree with someone.
column11: He was brutally honest about his feelings.
column12: The film is a brutally realistic depiction of war.

column9: to go to a place.
column10: Now it's time for you to head over to the test area...
column11: Let's head over to the park.
column12: I'm going to head over to the library to do some studying.

column9: exercises where you rewrite a sentence so that it has a different structure but the same meaning.
column10: ...you will find all kinds of lovely lovely sentence transformations.
column11: Sentence transformations are a common feature of Cambridge exams.
column12: This exercise is to practise sentence transformations with conditional clauses.

column9: to recognize a line from a song.
column10: Extra points for those of you who can spot the Beatles lyric in the test...
column11: I love playing 'spot the lyric' on the radio.
column12: Did you spot the lyric from that famous song in his speech?

column9: without conscious thought; by natural instinct.
column10: ...do them quite instinctively in order to speak fluently.
column11: He instinctively put out his hand to stop her from falling.
column12: She instinctively knew that something was wrong.

column9: to become very skilled at these things.
column10: You need to be able to master these things in order to become an advanced or proficient user of English.
column11: It takes years of practice to master a musical instrument.
column12: She has managed to master the art of negotiation.

column9: rude or offensive words.
column10: ...inversions with a couple of rude swear words.
column11: The film was full of swear words.
column12: He got into trouble for using swear words in class.

column9: the act of telling your employer that you are leaving your job.
column10: ...MPs were calling for his resignation.
column11: He handed in his resignation yesterday.
column12: There have been calls for the minister's resignation.

column9: acts of showing a quality or feeling.
column10: ...such amazing displays of political maneuvering.
column11: The team gave a brilliant display of attacking football.
column12: There were public displays of grief after the tragedy.

column9: the feeling of being upset or angry at something that somebody has said or done.
column10: In no way did I intend to cause offence with my words.
column11: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to cause any offence.
column12: He took offence at her comments.

column9: a meeting in which people are given information or instructions.
column10: ...should you talk to the press before our briefing.
column11: There will be a briefing for all staff at 9am.
column12: The soldiers were given a briefing before the mission.

column9: to stop feeling angry or resentful towards (someone) for an offence, flaw, or mistake.
column10: ...did the nation choose to forgive him.
column11: I'll never forgive him for what he did.
column12: It's important to be able to forgive and forget.

column9: a polite way of asking a question.
column10: I don't suppose you have any idea where this train goes?
column11: I don't suppose you could lend me some money, could you?
column12: I don't suppose you know the time, do you?

column9: (of a process or machine) working by itself with little or no direct human control.
column10: Practice makes perfect, so let's go... until it becomes automatic.
column11: The doors are automatic.
column12: The car has an automatic gearbox.
